entry.title: Independent Judgement and Responsibility
entry.content:
Description

  • Refusing work because of not charted
  • Taking decisions without a senior engineer
  • Taking taught decision
  • Responsibility of actions
  • Responsibility of people wellbeing

This is about taking decisions and identifying my strengths and weaknesses.

Examples

I believe that my main strengths are my solid technical and analytical knowledge in engineering, great attention to detail and my advance computer knowledge on multiple software.

Enfield Care home

In 2014 Atkins decided to move into BIM level 2 and the Colchester office didn’t had a BIM manager neither a BIM designer at the time. Having a solid knowledge on multiple software I stepped forward to take the lead as a BIM office champion. I have asked to go to Revit training and practiced through small Revit projects. On February Atkins Colchester had won a 3 storey new build care home project in London Enfield. I then approached my structures line manager and suggested to do the complete structural design, analysis and drawings through Revit- Robot package.

By the time the initial architect and M&E models where in 2D cad formats. Having created the first draft structures 3D model I shared the it with the other disciplines and they decided to follow our structures lead. I became the BIM Coordinators for the project and helped the other disciplines to set-up their models. For the structural analysis I did integrate the Revit model with the Robot structural software but honestly is far from perfect. I ended up setting up the model from scratch more than 10 times and constantly changing the model many times.

Refusing work because of not charted

In Domenica Group developers I was responsible for the design and analysis of the residential buildings. Also I was responsible for the preparing the paperwork for the permit submission. On the day of the submission our senior civil engineer wasn’t in the office and my manager asked my to signed the drawings instead because we had to submit that day. Although it was similar to others we had submitted already and I was confident of the design, I wasn’t charted at the time and I refused to do so.

Taking decisions without a senior engineer

On call, taking initiative – no support of senior engineers.

Responsibility of actions

Messogi villas was a project of three 2 storey villas built at north of Paphos town. Previously I had done draft electrical design in residential houses (plugs and sockets required) and further passing them to our electrical contractor to amend and finalise the design. For the specific project the contractor had asked me to develop a draft copy but I had 4 other project to work on. At the time of the submissions the drawings weren’t ready and it was a lot of blame on the electrical contractor since he is mainly responsible for the design. I took the blame since I promised to do a draft and stayed overtime that day to deliver.

Taking taught decision

Decision not to employ sub-contractors that didn’t deliver.

Responsibility of people wellbeing
entry.summary: Description Refusing work because of not charted Taking decisions without a senior engineer Taking taught decision Responsibility of actions Responsibility of people wellbeing

entry.title: Commercial Ability
entry.content:
Description

Clients, Competitors, Suppliers

  • Working with client, Costain, Dan, NR, MTR
  • Attending meetings with clients
    • Always organised to show strength
    • Defend the firm
  • Budget control
  • Contract knowledge/ Awareness
  • Everyday client interaction
    • Careful with confidential data
      • Not gave in to client pressure
  • Suppliers

entry.title: Health, Safety and Welfare
entry.content:
Description

  • Hazard meetings and Hazard logs
  • On site
    • Challenge: Uncovered manholes, exposed wires,
    • Right PPE, Always
  • On drawings pass of info
    • Hazard triangles
    • SHE box

PTS

  • 3 day training
    • On site
  • CSCS
  • AOS – company polices
  • Access on site
  • Managing risk on site
  • CDM knowledge
  • How did I mitigate risk on site/ design
  • Safe by design

  • Team safety

  • Know the Legislation

Examples

Hazard meetings and Hazard logs

As the lead engineer on the platform extension KO1 project I have participated in HAZID workshop were all the discipline lead and the safety team brainstorm to identify all the potential hazards our design may arise.

HAZID Objective: To identify the potential hazards and to reduce the probability and consequences of an incident in site that would have a detrimental impact to the personnel plant, properties and environment.

One of my responsibilities was to fill the hazard logs where I was required to respond to the potential hazards that were identified in the HAZID. I was responsible to provide all the measurements that were taken to eliminate the hazards or reduce the risk (Standards, mitigation actions etc.) provide evidence (drawings, Form A/B, notes etc.), identify residual risks and suggest mitigations.

Rise of early warning.

On Ilford station, platform 2 CE, the operation limit of the 345 train extends approximately 2.0m into non-compliant platform (platform width is less than 2.5m). An option to shift the operational limit towards the LE is possible since the platform extension on the LE has adequate length of compliant platform. In this case an impact assessment of the shift must be done on the DOO system/equipment.”

Site visits

Chloraka Nest Cyprus – Villas

Health and Safety at work place law of 1995 and the 2011 amendment clearly sets out the principals of privation, risk assessment and responsibilities of the employer and employees in Cyprus. Unfortunately, enforcement of the laws wasn’t strict on the construction site and a lot of the basic principles of the personal safety were ignored by the contractors and the workers.
For the Chloraka Nest project I held the role of the supervising site engineer. Having experience as a construction worker from my summer placements I implemented strict PPE and working on heights safety rules. No entrance would be allowed to anyone that would not follow the rules.
In the beginning I struggled a lot to implement the rules since I was young and most of the workers were old and stubborn. But through talks I managed to convince them that I’s for their own safety and the ones working around them.

Enfield Care Home (Challenge: Uncovered manholes, exposed wires)

After we finalised our design I was responsible to technically support the client (Morgan Sindall) on technical issues rising on site, therefore I was visiting the site every fortnight to assess and support the site. During my visits, I have identified various hazards on site i.e. uncovered manholes and un restrained riser holes.

Ely House Chimney

I was responsibly to carry out a survey and an assessment of a concrete chimney removal due to the boiler system replacement that didn’t require to have one. On site the scaffolds were installed from the previous day by the contractor who wasn’t on site at the time. I had to climb to the top of the chimney to assess the condition of the concrete cap; before climbing I always check the certificate and visually assessed the scaffolding. The main ladder that was reaching to the middle of the chimney, about 4m, was only fixed on the top which made it wobbly and sway. I immediately stopped the survey and called to contractor to secure the ladder and rescheduled my visit.

Personal Track Safety (PTS)/ CSCS

Working for the Crossrail project I have gain a lot of experience in the safety department. Rail site are very dangerous places and the knowledge how to safely operate there is very crucial. I did a three days training (office and site) and obtained the PTS card that made me aware of all the hazards when working on or near the line. By knowing the dangers that a rail site has, made me more conscious on my designs as well. I also have a CSCS card.

PPE

Wear the appropriate PPE (personal protective equipment). This includes safety boots, a hard hat (white or blue) and orange high visibility clothing

AOS – company polices

Atkins Operating Safely (AOS) is a bespoke system designed to help keep our people safe when they are travelling, undertaking site activities and visiting unfamiliar offices Every time I am visiting a client location or site all aspects must be covered by the AOS form. To fill the form, I am planning my visit; which route I’ll take and the safest transportation available; carrying out a risk assessment of the site I am visiting (i.e. slips and trips, asbestos, contaminated water etc.); Choosing the appropriate PPE; getting my line managers approval and always make sure to stay in touch via online or phone system, while I am there.

On drawings pass of info

I have been delivering drawings for Crossrail for the past year and the safety information is very critical. NR site are multidisciplinary and old inherent risk are in abundance and tricky to identify. To pass the risk information on the drawings I was identified Hazard Triangles (structure potential of clash, electrical cable exposure, chemical exposure, confined spaces etc.) and filling the SHE box (operational risk i.e. platform not be become operational before mid-platform fence installation, damaging existing services, instabilities).

Access on site

I have been doing several site visits for the Crossrail KO1 and platform extension projects.

CDM knowledge

I had a one day training on the Principal designer duties according to the CDM 2015.

How did I mitigate risk on site? Take any measurement to prevent accidents, always use appropriate route, wear the right PPE, be aware of the ones around you.

Safe by design

An all my designs I periodically step back to analyse the buildability and the occupational hazards I may introduce. Most of the risk and accidents happen on site, can be traced back to the design. -example of mitigate risk

Objective: Prevention through design represents a shift in approach for on-the-job safety. It involves evaluating potential risks associated with processes, structures, equipment, and tools. It takes into consideration the construction, maintenance, decommissioning, and disposal or recycling of waste material

Team safety

I have been taking graduate engineers with me on site to expand their experience. I let them first to address the risks and the action we must take and then help them to understand why we need. On Ely House and Duke street we had to survey a concrete cap on the top of a chimney and lintel & wall cracks on the 3rd floor respectively. Both sites had exterior scaffolding and required to climb ladder to reach heights of 3-4m. After checking myself I let George to check the certificate and stability of the scaffolding himself and challenge the contractor if any doubt. Asking if he’s comfortable to climb and only then to proceed. Both times he was confident to do so and I was guiding him through the process.

Know the Legislation

Important legislations: The Corporate Manslaughter and Corporate Homicide Act 2007, he Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974.
entry.summary: Description Hazard meetings and Hazard logs On site Challenge: Uncovered manholes, exposed wires, Right PPE, Always On drawings pass of info Hazard triangles SHE box

entry.title: Interpersonal Skills and Communication
entry.content:
Description

  • Working with GDC
  • Language barrier – other ways of communication
  • Communication through drawings, sketches, reports, presentations, email, phone
  • Different approach to different people -technical, non-technical
  • LGBT

Examples

As a foreigner myself I had to surpass many language and cultural barriers and adapt to the new community I was part of. I constantly keep practicing my linguistic skills trying to make friends of different ethnicities and learn their values. Working in a multicultural environment we need to respect each other’s values, religions and beliefs.

Cyprus

In Domenica Group our main clients were foreigners form UK, China and Russia, so every time I had to adapt how to deal with different cultures. Being polite and having patience are the best tools, making others feel confident and understanding.

Working with Global Design Centre (GDC)

Diversity

In Atkins, we are a multi-discipline, multi-office and multinational company. Working with different people with different background and ethnicity in day-to-day bases cultivated how we behave. In the office, I try to make friend from different ethnicities, joining on lunch break and going to the socials.

I completely avoid stereotypes and try to view everyone as individual.

  • Do you test your assumptions before acting on them?
  • Do you believe there is only one right way of doing things, or that there are a number of valid ways that accomplish the same goal? Do you convey that to staff?
  • Do you have honest relationships with each staff member you supervise? Are you comfortable with each of them? Do you know what motivates them, what their goals are, how they like to be recognized?
  • Are you able to give negative feedback to someone who is culturally different from you?
  • When you have open positions, do you insist on a diverse screening committee and make additional outreach efforts to ensure that a diverse pool of candidates has applied?
  • When you hire a new employee, do you not only explain job responsibilities and expectations clearly, but orient the person to the campus and department culture and unwritten rules?
  • Do you rigorously examine your unit’s existing policies, practices, and procedures to ensure that they do not differentially impact different groups? When they do, do you change them?
  • Are you willing to listen to constructive feedback from your staff about ways to improve the work environment? Do you implement staff suggestions and acknowledge their contribution?
  • Do you take immediate action with people you supervise when they behave in ways that show disrespect for others in the workplace, such as inappropriate jokes and offensive terms?
  • Do you make good faith efforts to meet your affirmative action goals?
  • Do you have a good understanding of institutional isms such as racism and sexism and how they manifest themselves in the workplace?
  • Do you ensure that assignments and opportunities for advancement are accessible to everyone?

Working with clients and other offices.

On the Crossrail KO1S&G project we were working hand to hand with a large team in Bangalore and Deli. The team consisted from Civil design eng, civil design check eng, cad technicians, cad checkers and package managers. The team communication and the stream of information was very crucial for success.

The barrier of language and to being able to pass the information that you wanted was challenging. From my experience, Indian people are very polite and a lot of times in our discussion they wouldn’t disagree and or ask to explain something even if they would not understand. Realising that I would always encourage them to ask again and again if they were not completely sure what needed to be done.

The main way of communication was emails and skype voice and video calls. Being able to share the screen through skype and present the 3D model, the drawing etc., in real time was a powerful way to pass information avoiding explaining extensively.
Moreover, the 5.30 hours’ difference was quite challenging, by 12:00 o’clock UK time the GDC offices were closing leaving effectively only 3-4 hours of mutual working time. I managed to adapt by being more proactive and prepare the work package for the entire next day. Also, I had shift my working hours one hour earlier to expand the mutual working time.

Language barrier – other ways of communication

  • Communication by email is dominant by today standards but because everyone using them most of the time it becomes very overwhelming. Reading through dozens of emails becomes very overwhelming and time consuming.
    I did a toolbox talk discussing about the issue and explaining ways to reduce them. For example by thinking who we need to CC and if it’s quick a phone call is always a better way.

  • Communication through drawings, sketches, reports, presentations, email, phone.
    As engineers, we mainly communicate through drawings, sketches and reports. I make sure to use clear language, short notes and consistency of the information I try to pass.

  • Different approach to different people, Technical, non-technical
    I am adapting every time we communicate with someone, changing the language to more technical with engineers and les when communicating with people outside of our discipline ie clients.
entry.summary: Description Working with GDC Language barrier – other ways of communication Communication through drawings, sketches, reports, presentations, email, phone Different approach to different people -technical, non-technical LGBT

entry.title: Professional Commitment
entry.content:
Description

  • Read ICE code of Conduct
  • CPD submission
  • CPD attendance, taking people aboard
  • Ethical

Examples

Code of conduct

I have read the ICE code of conduct and I know the six Rules.

  1. All members shall discharge their professional duties with integrity and shall behave with integrity in relation to all conduct bearing upon the standing, reputation and dignity of the Institution and of the profession of civil engineering.
  2. All members shall only undertake work that they are competent to do.
  3. All members shall have full regard for the public interest, particularly in relation to matters of health and safety, and in relation to the well-being of future generations.
  4. All members shall show due regard for the environment and for the sustainable management of natural resources.
  5. All members shall develop their professional knowledge, skills and competence on a continuing basis and shall give all reasonable assistance to further the education, training and continuing professional development of others.
  6. All members shall:
    • a. notify the Institution if convicted of a criminal offence;
    • b. notify the Institution upon becoming bankrupt or disqualified as a Company Director;
    • c. notify the Institution of any significant breach of the Rules of Professional Conduct by another member.

CPD

CPD records and areas of interest

What I get back to society

What I want to be in 5 years’ time.

I will pass this and be at your side of the desk.

Chloraka Nest.

Offered gift

Very often after finishing the works on site I was offered gifts from the sub-contractors, usually the gifts were expensive liquor bottles. I never accepted the gifts explaining to them that my acceptance might change/compromise my actions/create obligation in the future. “Favourable treatment”

Diversity

Don’t treat everybody the same – Treat them as I would like to treat: WRONG Treat them according to their needs.

Office diversity of all races, colour and sexuality.

Personal Experience as an immigrant

3D Microstation training

As part of our team competency for the Crossrail project was a 3D training of the Microstation software, since all the project development is within the Bentley ecosystem. Having advance skills in computers I proposed to be seated next to our senior line manager, who usually struggles with the software, so I can provide extra help and guidance during the training.

Discrimination

Equality Act 2010. Age, gender, race, sexuality, marriage, pregnancy, disability,
entry.summary: Description Read ICE code of Conduct CPD submission CPD attendance, taking people aboard Ethical
